questiontext.text:
The following questions use ZZ to refer to the standard normal variable. You will determine some probabilities and some boundaries.

  1. Determine zz such that P(Z<z)=0.7454P(Z<z)=0.7454 {1:NUMERICAL:=0.66:0.01~%0%312820464:0}
  2. Determine P(−1.19<Z<1.19)P(-1.19<Z<1.19) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.766:0.01~%0%312820464:0}
  3. Determine P(Z<−0.1)P(Z<-0.1) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.4602:0.01~%0%312820464:0}
  4. Determine P(Z>0.29)P(Z>0.29) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.3859:0.01~%0%312820464:0}
  5. Determine zz such that P(Z>z)=0.305P(Z>z)=0.305 {1:NUMERICAL:=0.51:0.01~%0%312820464:0}

generalfeedback.text:
To do this problem, you should practice the Standard Normal exercises.

  1. 0.66
  2. 0.766
  3. 0.4602
  4. 0.3859
  5. 0.51

questiontext.text:
Let random variable XX be normally distributed with mean μ=40\mu=40 and standard deviation σ=7\sigma=7.

  1. Determine P(32.3<X<47.7)P(32.3<X<47.7) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.7286:0.01~%0%775190355:0}
  2. Determine xx such that P(X>x)=0.3821P(X>x)=0.3821 {1:NUMERICAL:=42.1:0.1~%0%775190355:0}
  3. Determine P(X<29.5)P(X<29.5) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.0668:0.01~%0%775190355:0}
  4. Determine P(X>35.1)P(X>35.1) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.758:0.01~%0%775190355:0}
  5. Determine xx such that P(X<x)=0.0035P(X<x)=0.0035 {1:NUMERICAL:=21.1:0.1~%0%775190355:0}

generalfeedback.text:
1. Identify the boundaries.x1=32.3x_1=32.3x2=47.7x_2=47.7Get the z scores.z1=x1−μσ=−1.1z_1=\frac{x_1-\mu}{\sigma}=-1.1z2=x2−μσ=1.1z_2=\frac{x_2-\mu}{\sigma}=1.1With zz-table, determine P(−1.1<Z<1.1)=0.7286P(-1.1<Z<1.1)=0.7286
  2. Determine zz such that P(Z>z)=0.6179P(Z>z)=0.6179.z=0.3z=0.3Calculate the boundary xx.x=μ+zσ=42.1x=\mu+z\sigma=42.1
  3. Identify the boundary.x=29.5x=29.5Get the z score.z=x−μσ=−1.5z=\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}=-1.5With zz-table, determine P(Z<−1.5)=0.0668P(Z<-1.5)=0.0668
  4. Identify the boundary.x=35.1x=35.1Get the z score.z=x−μσ=−0.7z=\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}=-0.7With zz-table, determine P(Z>−0.7)=0.758P(Z>-0.7)=0.758
  5. Determine zz such that P(Z<z)=0.0035P(Z<z)=0.0035.z=−2.7z=-2.7Calculate the boundary xx.x=μ+zσ=21.1x=\mu+z\sigma=21.1

questiontext.text:
Population

Random variable XX has mean μ=45\mu=45 and standard deviation σ=9\sigma=9.

Interval of typical measurements

Let the interval of typical measurements be defined as having lower bound μ−2σ\mu-2\sigma and upper bound μ+2σ\mu+2\sigma. interval of typical measurements=(μ−2σ,μ+2σ)\text{interval of typical measurements} = (\mu-2\sigma, \, \mu+2\sigma)

Calculate the lower bound of the interval of typical measurements. {1:NUMERICAL:=27:0.1~%0%875158:0}

Calculate the upper bound of the interval of typical measurements. {1:NUMERICAL:=63:0.1~%0%875158:0}

Interval of typical totals

Let the interval of typical totals be defined as having lower bound nμ−2σnn\mu-2\sigma\sqrt{n} and upper bound nμ+2σnn\mu+2\sigma\sqrt{n}. interval of typical totals=(nμ−2σn,nμ+2σn)\text{interval of typical totals} = \left(n\mu-2\sigma\sqrt{n}, \, n\mu+2\sigma\sqrt{n}\right)

For the listed values of nn, determine the bounds.

nn _ lower bound of typical totals _ _ upper bound of typical totals _
25 {1:NUMERICAL:=1035:0.1~%0%875158:0} {1:NUMERICAL:=1215:0.1~%0%875158:0}
100 {1:NUMERICAL:=4320:0.1~%0%875158:0} {1:NUMERICAL:=4680:0.1~%0%875158:0}
400 {1:NUMERICAL:=17640:0.1~%0%875158:0} {1:NUMERICAL:=18360:0.1~%0%875158:0}

Interval of typical averages

Let the interval of typical averages be defined as having lower bound μ−2σn\mu-\frac{2\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} and upper bound μ+2σn\mu+\frac{2\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}.

interval of typical averages=(μ−2σn,μ+2σn)\text{interval of typical averages} = \left(\mu-\frac{2\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}, \, \mu+\frac{2\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\right) For the listed values of nn, determine the bounds.

nn _ lower bound of typical averages _ _ upper bound of typical averages _
25 {1:NUMERICAL:=41.4:0.1~%0%875158:0} {1:NUMERICAL:=48.6:0.1~%0%875158:0}
100 {1:NUMERICAL:=43.2:0.1~%0%875158:0} {1:NUMERICAL:=46.8:0.1~%0%875158:0}
400 {1:NUMERICAL:=44.1:0.1~%0%875158:0} {1:NUMERICAL:=45.9:0.1~%0%875158:0}

generalfeedback.text:
Interval of typical measurements

lower bound=27\text{lower bound} = 27 upper bound=63\text{upper bound} = 63

Interval of typical totals

nn _ lower bound of typical totals _ _ upper bound of typical totals _
25 1035 1215
100 4320 4680
400 17640 18360

Interval of typical averages

nn _ lower bound of typical averages _ _ upper bound of typical averages _
25 41.4 48.6
100 43.2 46.8
400 44.1 45.9

questiontext.text:
Population

Random variable XX follows a Bernoulli distribution with p=0.51p=0.51. In this context, each spin is often called a trial. A “0” is a “fail” and a “1” is a “success”.


The average of a Bernoulli random variable is equal to pp. μ=p\mu=p Determine μ\mu. {1:NUMERICAL:=0.51:0.01~%0%1232461:0}

The standard deviation of a Bernoulli random variable is equal to p(1−p)\sqrt{p(1-p)}. σ=p(1−p)\sigma = \sqrt{p(1-p)} Determine σ\sigma. {1:NUMERICAL:=0.4999:0.001~%0%1232461:0} (Round to thousandths place.)

Interval of typical success totals

The binomial distribution predicts how many successes there will be for a given number of trials. Let the interval of typical successes be defined as having lower bound np−2np(1−p)np-2\sqrt{np(1-p)} and upper bound np+2np(1−p)np+2\sqrt{np(1-p)}. interval of typical successes=(np−2np(1−p),np+2np(1−p))\text{interval of typical successes} = \left(np-2\sqrt{np(1-p)}, \, np+2\sqrt{np(1-p)}\right)

For the listed values of nn, determine the bounds. (Round to nearest integer.)

nn _ lower bound of typical successes _ _ upper bound of typical successes _
25 {1:NUMERICAL:=8:1~%0%1232461:0} {1:NUMERICAL:=18:1~%0%1232461:0}
100 {1:NUMERICAL:=41:1~%0%1232461:0} {1:NUMERICAL:=61:1~%0%1232461:0}
400 {1:NUMERICAL:=184:1~%0%1232461:0} {1:NUMERICAL:=224:1~%0%1232461:0}

Interval of typical proportions

Let the interval of typical proportions be defined as having lower bound p−2p(1−p)np-2\sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} and upper bound p+2p(1−p)np+2\sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}.

interval of typical proportions=(p−2p(1−p)n,p+2p(1−p)n)\text{interval of typical proportions} = \left(p-2\sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}, \, p+2\sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}\right) For the listed values of nn, determine the bounds. (Round to nearest hundredth.)

nn _ lower bound of typical proportions _ _ upper bound of typical proportions _
25 {1:NUMERICAL:=0.31004:0.01~%0%1232461:0} {1:NUMERICAL:=0.70996:0.01~%0%1232461:0}
100 {1:NUMERICAL:=0.41002:0.01~%0%1232461:0} {1:NUMERICAL:=0.60998:0.01~%0%1232461:0}
400 {1:NUMERICAL:=0.46001:0.01~%0%1232461:0} {1:NUMERICAL:=0.55999:0.01~%0%1232461:0}

nn _ lower bound of typical successes _ _ upper bound of typical successes _

100 41 61
400 184 224

Interval of typical proportions

nn _ lower bound of typical proportions _ _ upper bound of typical proportions _
25 0.31 0.71
100 0.41 0.61
400 0.46 0.56

questiontext.text:
A farm produces 4 types of fruit: persimmons, papayas, lemons, and plums. The fruits’ masses have population parameters dependent on the type of fruit. (All values are in grams.)

_ Type of fruit _ _ Population mean (μ\mu) _ _ Population standard deviation (σ\sigma) _
persimmons 194 18
papayas 329 18
lemons 122 9
plums 72 4

A sample of each type is weighed. The results are shown below.

_ Type of fruit _ _ Sample size (nn) _ _ Sample mean (x‾\bar{x}) _
persimmon 81 193.5
papaya 25 333.7
lemon 49 120
plum 64 71.96

The population parameters and sample statistics can be downloaded as a csv.

For each sample, determine the mean’s standard score and the mean’s cumulative probability by assuming the requirements for the central limit theorem are met. Then determine which sample mean is most unusually large, most unusually small, most typically sized, and most unusually sized.

The standard score of a sample mean: z=x‾−μσ/nz = \frac{\bar{x}-\mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} Some people prefer to call this denominator the standard error. standard error of mean=SEM=σn\text{standard error of mean} = \text{SEM} = \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} So the standard score (zz-score) of a sample mean can also be expressed as z=x‾−μSEMz = \frac{\bar{x}-\mu}{\text{SEM}}

  1. Calculate a zz-score for the persimmon sample mean. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=-0.25:0.011}
  2. What proportion of persimmon samples of size n=81n=81 have a smaller mean than the persimmon sample? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.4013:0.01}
  3. Calculate a zz-score for the papaya sample mean. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=1.31:0.011}
  4. What proportion of papaya samples of size n=25n=25 have a smaller mean than the papaya sample? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.9049:0.01}
  5. Calculate a zz-score for the lemon sample mean. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=-1.56:0.011}
  6. What proportion of lemon samples of size n=49n=49 have a smaller mean than the lemon sample? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.0594:0.01}
  7. Calculate a zz-score for the plum sample mean. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=-0.08:0.011}
  8. What proportion of plum samples of size n=64n=64 have a smaller mean than the plum sample? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.4681:0.01}
  9. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The persimmon sample mean is most unusually large.~%100%The papaya sample mean is most unusually large.~%0%The lemon sample mean is most unusually large.~%0%The plum sample mean is most unusually large.}
  10. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The persimmon sample mean is most unusually small.~%0%The papaya sample mean is most unusually small.~%100%The lemon sample mean is most unusually small.~%0%The plum sample mean is most unusually small.}
  11. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The persimmon sample mean is most typically sized.~%0%The papaya sample mean is most typically sized.~%0%The lemon sample mean is most typically sized.~%100%The plum sample mean is most typically sized.}
  12. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The persimmon sample mean is most unusually sized.~%0%The papaya sample mean is most unusually sized.~%100%The lemon sample mean is most unusually sized.~%0%The plum sample mean is most unusually sized.}

generalfeedback.text:
The formula to determine the zz-score of a sample mean is the ratio with numerator the difference between measurement and population mean and denominator the standard error of the mean.

z=x‾−μσ/nz = \frac{\bar{x}-\mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}}

The highest zz-score (furthest right on number line) corresponds to the most unusually large sample mean.

The smallest zz-score (furthest left on number line) corresponds to the most unusually small sample mean.

The smallest absolute zz-score corresponds to the most usually sized sample mean.

The largest absolute zz-score corresponds to the most unusually sized sample mean.

Spreadsheet:

By using the formulas, you should get a spreadsheet like the one displayed here:


To do this in R:

data = read.csv("fruit.csv", as.is=TRUE)
fruit = data$fruit
mu = data$mu
sigma = data$sigma
n = data$n
xbar = data$xbar

SEM = sigma/sqrt(n)
z = round( (xbar-mu)/SEM ,2)
cum_prob = round( pnorm(z) ,4)
data.frame(data,SEM,z,cum_prob,abs(z))
##       fruit  mu sigma  n   xbar      SEM     z cum_prob abs.z.
## 1 persimmon 194    18 81 193.50 2.000000 -0.25   0.4013   0.25
## 2    papaya 329    18 25 333.70 3.600000  1.31   0.9049   1.31
## 3     lemon 122     9 49 120.00 1.285714 -1.56   0.0594   1.56
## 4      plum  72     4 64  71.96 0.500000 -0.08   0.4681   0.08
# Most unusually large
fruit[z==max(z)]
## [1] "papaya"
# Most unusually small
fruit[z==min(z)]
## [1] "lemon"
# Most typically sized
fruit[abs(z)==min(abs(z))]
## [1] "plum"
# Most unusually sized
fruit[abs(z)==max(abs(z))]
## [1] "lemon"
  1. We use the formula for calculating the persimmon sample-mean zz score. z=193.5−19418/81=−0.25z = \frac{193.5-194}{18/\sqrt{81}} = -0.25
  2. Use the zz table to find the cumulative probability. P(Z<−0.25)=0.4013P(Z<-0.25) = 0.4013
  3. We use the formula for calculating the papaya sample-mean zz score. z=333.7−32918/25=1.31z = \frac{333.7-329}{18/\sqrt{25}} = 1.31
  4. Use the zz table to find the cumulative probability. P(Z<1.31)=0.9049P(Z<1.31) = 0.9049
  5. We use the formula for calculating the lemon sample-mean zz score. z=120−1229/49=−1.56z = \frac{120-122}{9/\sqrt{49}} = -1.56
  6. Use the zz table to find the cumulative probability. P(Z<−1.56)=0.0594P(Z<-1.56) = 0.0594
  7. We use the formula for calculating the plum sample-mean zz score. z=71.96−724/64=−0.08z = \frac{71.96-72}{4/\sqrt{64}} = -0.08
  8. Use the zz table to find the cumulative probability. P(Z<−0.08)=0.4681P(Z<-0.08) = 0.4681
  9. We determine the maximum zz score is 1.311.31, which belongs to the papaya. / . / . / .
  10. We determine the minimum zz score is −1.56-1.56, which belongs to the lemon. / . / . / .
  11. We determine the minimum absolute zz score is 0.080.08, which belongs to the plum. / . / . / .
  12. We determine the maximum absolute zz score is 1.561.56, which belongs to the lemon. / . / . / .

questiontext.text:
This question provides μ\mu, σ\sigma, nn, and ∑x\sum x. You will characterize the sampling distribution, calculate the standard score, determine the percentile rank (expressed as a decimal), and translate the score into a rating (see below).

Population

When Archie practices archery, each arrow has the same probability distribution (see i.i.d). This means her skill is constant, there is no hot-hand effect, and there is no maturity of chances.

Over many months, Archie has shot ten thousand arrows (their positions are shown below as dots).


From those many arrows, Archie has determined an accurate probability distribution (of the points scored by an arrow).


Thus, Archie can determine her population mean and population standard deviation. μ=7.97\mu=7.97 σ=1.66\sigma=1.66

Sampling distribution

Each day, Archie shoots 108 arrows (n=108n=108) and determines that day’s total score. A total of 1080 would be a perfect day. We can treat each day’s total as a random variable with its own probability distribution: a sampling distribution. We wish to characterize this sampling distribution. From the central limit theorem, we know the sampling distribution is approximately normal; however, we need to calculate the parameters.

Expected total (mean of sampling distribution)

The expected total is the product of the sample size and the population mean. expected total=nμ\text{expected total} = n\mu

“Expected total” is a misnomer. It is not necessarily likely, or even possible, for a total to equal the expected total. However, if Archie repeatedly shot 108 arrows, we expect the totals to have a mean equal to the expected total. So, maybe “average of totals” would be better terminology.

This expected total is the average of the sampling distribution.

Calculate the expected total: {1:NUMERICAL:=860.76:2~%0%199235437:0}

(Round to the hundredths place)

Standard error (standard deviation of sampling distribution)

The standard error of a total is the product of the population standard deviation and the square root of the sample size. standard error of total=σn\text{standard error of total} = \sigma \sqrt{n} This standard error is the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.

Calculate the standard error: {1:NUMERICAL:=17.251226:2~%0%199235437:0}

(Round to the hundredths place)

Sample

Today, Archie’s total score is 849 points (∑x=849\sum x = 849).


Standard score

Archie would like to know how well she did today. She wants you to calculate a standard score (a zz score). To calculate the standard score of a sample total, you can use the following formula. z=∑x−nμσnz = \frac{\sum x - n\mu}{\sigma\sqrt{n}}

Calculate the standard score: {1:NUMERICAL:=-0.68:0.02~%0%199235437:0}

(Round to the hundredths place)

Cumulative probability (percentile rank)

Archie would like to know the probability that tomorrow she shoots worse than today. To estimate this, report the cumulative probability associated with the standard score you calculated. This can be done with a zz table, pnorm function in R, NORM.DIST function in a spreadsheet, or with other standard normal tools.

Calculate P(Z≤z)P(Z\leq z), the cumulative probability: {1:NUMERICAL:=0.2482522:0.001~%0%199235437:0}

(Round to the ten-thousandths place)

Rating

Archie would like a rating for her day’s performance. You decide to use the following scale and that if zz is on a boundary, Archie will be given the higher rating.

zz interval rating
−∞-\infty to -1.5 F
-1.5 to -0.5 D
-0.5 to 0.5 C
0.5 to 1.5 B
1.5 to ∞\infty A


Determine Archie’s rating: {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%A~%0%B~%0%C~%100%D~%0%F}

generalfeedback.text:
The sampling distribution is approximately normal with mean 860.76 and standard error 17.25. The sampling distribution can be visualized, along with today’s total (849) highlighted in red. The cumulative probability is the sum of the probabilities of scores less than (or equal) 849. Thus, the area highlighted in blue represents the cumulative probability.


  1. The expected total is nμ=860.76n\mu = 860.76
  2. The standard error is σn=17.25\sigma \sqrt{n} = 17.25
  3. Use the formula to calculate z=−0.68z=-0.68
  4. Use the zz table to find P(Z≤z)=0.2483P(Z\le z) = 0.2483
  5. The proper rating is D / The proper rating is D / The proper rating is D / The proper rating is D / The proper rating is D

questiontext.text:
Random variable XX is normally distributed with mean μ=50\mu=50 and standard deviation σ=3\sigma=3. X∼N(50,3)X \sim N(50, 3)

  1. If n=25n=25, determine P(X¯>49.71)P\left(\overline{X}>49.71\right) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.6844:0.01~%0%165182:0}
  2. If n=64n=64, determine P(∑X<3192)P\left(\sum X <3192\right) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.3707:0.01~%0%165182:0}
  3. If n=144n=144, determine P(∑X>7183)P\left(\sum X >7183\right) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.6808:0.01~%0%165182:0}
  4. If n=121n=121, determine P(X¯<50.23)P\left(\overline{X}<50.23\right) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.7995:0.01~%0%165182:0}
  5. Determine P(X<49.2)P(X<49.2) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.3936:0.01~%0%165182:0}
  6. Determine P(X>48.6)P(X>48.6) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.6808:0.01~%0%165182:0}

generalfeedback.text:
1. Identify the boundary.x‾=49.71\bar{x}=49.71Calculate the standard error (of mean)SE=σn=0.6\text{SE} = \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}=0.6Get the z score.z=x‾−μSE=−0.48z=\frac{\bar{x}-\mu}{\text{SE}}=-0.48With zz-table, determine P(Z>−0.48)=0.6844P(Z>-0.48)=0.6844
  2. Identify the boundary.∑x=3192\sum x=3192Calculate the standard error (of total)SE=σn=24\text{SE} = \sigma\sqrt{n}=24Get the z score.z=∑x−nμSE=−0.33z=\frac{\sum x-n\mu}{\text{SE}}=-0.33With zz-table, determine P(Z<−0.33)=0.3707P(Z<-0.33)=0.3707
  3. Identify the boundary.∑x=7183\sum x=7183Calculate the standard error (of total)SE=σn=36\text{SE} = \sigma\sqrt{n}=36Get the z score.z=∑x−nμSE=−0.47z=\frac{\sum x-n\mu}{\text{SE}}=-0.47With zz-table, determine P(Z>−0.47)=0.6808P(Z>-0.47)=0.6808
  4. Identify the boundary.x‾=50.23\bar{x}=50.23Calculate the standard error (of mean)SE=σn=0.27273\text{SE} = \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}=0.27273Get the z score.z=x‾−μSE=0.84z=\frac{\bar{x}-\mu}{\text{SE}}=0.84With zz-table, determine P(Z<0.84)=0.7995P(Z<0.84)=0.7995
  5. Identify the boundary.x=49.2x=49.2Get the z score.z=x−μσ=−0.27z=\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}=-0.27With zz-table, determine P(Z<−0.27)=0.3936P(Z<-0.27)=0.3936
  6. Identify the boundary.x=48.6x=48.6Get the z score.z=x−μσ=−0.47z=\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}=-0.47With zz-table, determine P(Z>−0.47)=0.6808P(Z>-0.47)=0.6808

questiontext.text:
In some game, each trial has chance p=0.67p=0.67 of success. In other words, XX is a random Bernoulli variable with parameter p=0.67p=0.67. To determine the following probabilities, use the de Moivre–Laplace theorem (normal approximation). I have already done the continuity correction by setting the boundaries.

  1. If n=36n=36, what is the probability that the sample proportion (p̂\hat{p}) is less than 0.625? In other words, if n=36n=36, determine P(X¯<0.625)P\left(\overline{X}<0.625\right).In other words, if n=36n=36, determine P(p̂<0.625)P\left(\hat{p}<0.625\right). {1:NUMERICAL:=0.2843:0.01~%0%136113:0}
  2. If n=81n=81, what is the chance the number of successes is more than 56.5? In other words, if n=81n=81, determine P(∑X>56.5)P\left(\sum X >56.5\right) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.2981:0.01~%0%136113:0}
  3. If n=64n=64, what is the probability that the sample proportion (p̂\hat{p}) is more than 0.6172? In other words, if n=64n=64, determine P(X¯>0.6172)P\left(\overline{X}>0.6172\right).In other words, if n=64n=64, determine P(p̂>0.6172)P\left(\hat{p}>0.6172\right). {1:NUMERICAL:=0.8159:0.01~%0%136113:0}
  4. If n=49n=49, what is the chance the number of successes is less than 36.5? In other words, if n=49n=49, determine P(∑X<36.5)P\left(\sum X <36.5\right) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.8665:0.01~%0%136113:0}

generalfeedback.text:
You could first determine the mean and standard deviation of the Bernoulli variable XX.

μ=p=0.67\mu = p = 0.67 σ=p(1−p)=0.470213\sigma = \sqrt{p(1-p)} = 0.470213

  1. Identify the boundary.p̂=0.625\hat{p}=0.625Calculate the standard error (of proportion sampling)SE=σn=p(1−p)n=0.078369\text{SE} = \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}= \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} = 0.078369Get the z score.z=p̂−μSE=−0.57z=\frac{\hat{p}-\mu}{\text{SE}}=-0.57With zz-table, determine P(Z<−0.57)=0.2843P(Z<-0.57)=0.2843
  2. Identify the boundary.∑x=56.5\sum x=56.5Calculate the standard error (of total)SE=σn=np(1−p)=4.2319\text{SE} = \sigma\sqrt{n}=\sqrt{np(1-p)} =4.2319Get the z score.z=∑x−nμSE=0.53z=\frac{\sum x-n\mu}{\text{SE}}=0.53With zz-table, determine P(Z>0.53)=0.2981P(Z>0.53)=0.2981
  3. Identify the boundary.p̂=0.6172\hat{p}=0.6172Calculate the standard error (of proportion sampling)SE=σn=p(1−p)n=0.058777\text{SE} = \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}=\sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} =0.058777Get the z score.z=p̂−μSE=−0.9z=\frac{\hat{p}-\mu}{\text{SE}}=-0.9With zz-table, determine P(Z>−0.9)=0.8159P(Z>-0.9)=0.8159
  4. Identify the boundary.∑x=36.5\sum x=36.5Calculate the standard error (of total)SE=σn=np(1−p)=3.2915\text{SE} = \sigma\sqrt{n}=\sqrt{np(1-p)} =3.2915Get the z score.z=∑x−nμSE=1.11z=\frac{\sum x-n\mu}{\text{SE}}=1.11With zz-table, determine P(Z<1.11)=0.8665P(Z<1.11)=0.8665
